text.p: The following Australian economic indicators and events are scheduled for this week.
DAY GMT Indicator Period Forecast Previous
Mon 0030 Private new capex Q3 -3.0 pct +16.0 pct
Thur 0800 RBA governor Macfarlane gives speech
Fri 0030 Balance of payments Oct A$1.6 bln A$1.69
Fri 0030 Vehicle registrations Oct -0.5 pct +0.2 pct
Mon-Fri Department of Industrial Relations may release
quarterly data on enterprise bargain deals ---------------Calendar for Dec 2 week--------------------------

BUSINESS INVESTMENT - These figures will be critical both for the outlook for the economy and monetary policy in the months ahead. In particular, any backtracking on investment intentions would be of major concern to the government, which is looking for 14 percent growth in 1996/97 and the Reserve Bank which has highlighted investment as the "linchpin of forecast growth". Forecasts for private capital expenditure (Capex) in the September quarter centered on a fall of 3.0 percent to A$10.06 billion, but views were wildly divergent with estimates range from a rise of 2.5 percent to a fall of 15 percent.

Of equal importance would be the survey of business expectations for investment in the whole 1996/97 fiscal year. In the last survey the expectations had been for spending of A$39.34 billion in 1996/97 -- which if realised as in the past would deliver a 12.7 percent rise in nominal spending. To be consistent with government forecasts, a rise of around four percent on that was needed to A$41-42 billion in Monday's release.

BALANCE OF PAYMENTS - Imports are already known to have risen 1.3 percent in October so exports will need to rise to stop the deficit widening from September A$1.69 billion. One unknown will be the net income deficit since the Bureau of Statistics will have new data on Q3 foreign investment to plug into its series. So far the ABS has only been estimating the net income shortfall based on past trends this could cause revisions to past deficits. The makrets are generally comfortable with the deficit at current levels and only a widening to A$2.0 billion or more would alarm.
